content_html:
Accepting Impermanence

How I learned to love Samsara

Jackie Thornhill
Apr 2

According to the Buddhist philosophy, the reality of existence is characterized by three distinct marks, impermanence, suffering, and non-self.

While these adjectives may initially seem to paint a bleak picture of the world, upon closer examination they are actually core tenets of an ideology centered around a unique cosmological and spiritual view of reality.

The idea of impermanence is crucial in Buddhism, as it posits that what we might cling to as permanent in our lives is all ultimately temporary. In the most basic scientific sense, this makes perfect sense.

For example — the half life of uranium might be an unfathomable period of time in the context of a human life, but nevertheless it remains an impermanent substance that will break down over time. Nothing exists forever, as the atoms that compose the world around us constantly take new forms.

Additionally, the idea of suffering is woven throughout the entirety of Buddhism. While some might think of suffering as a response to negative stimuli, whether it be physical or emotional pain, the Buddhist view goes a little deeper in examining the nature of suffering.

Rather than seeing suffering as an avoidable response to negative situations, Buddhism views suffering as an unavoidable consequence of attachment. Anything that gives us joy to acquire and joy to keep will inevitably cause us to suffer when we lose it.

Considering the impermanent nature of reality, anybody who attaches themselves to anything, be it an object, person, or place, is destined to suffer as a consequence. The third and final mark of reality is the concept of non-self, the idea that a person’s conceptualization of themselves is entirely impermanent and subject to change.

This is arguably the most difficult mark of reality to accept, as it requires us to let go of any concept of self that we may have acquired while existing in samsara and accept the transient, impermanent nature of reality — even when it comes to our own bodies.

This is difficult because we like to think of our lives as linear narratives that unfold at a daily pace, acted out by one evolving but ultimately unchanging person and bookended by our births and deaths. In reality, however, we are many different ‘selves’, there is no one unchanging being that remains with us throughout samsara.

In this way, the concept of non-self fits in well with the concepts of impermanence and suffering, as the nature of one’s own being is always impermanent and we only subject ourselves to suffering by growing attached to a concrete concept of self.

In Buddhist tradition many things that might otherwise be thought of as whole are broken down into smaller, more digestible parts. Existence is defined by three marks, reality broken up into six realms, and the body broken up into thirty-two unique parts. This distinction plays an especially important role when considering both the inevitability of suffering and the desire to escape it.

Professor of Buddhist studies Rupert Gethin writes, “There is some reason for thinking that the number thirty-two connotes completion and fulfillment in Buddhist thought: the body is described as consisting of thirty-two parts; the Great Man has a body with thirty-two marks. Yet samsara has only thirty-one realms.”

Gethin demonstrates the complexity of the concept of non-self and highlights the inescapability of suffering fwhile still allowing for the eventual escape from samsara. The self consists of thirty-two unique parts which aligns almost perfectly with the thirty-one realms of which samsara is made up, while providing for an alternative that represents nirvana.

This is exemplary of the Buddhist philosophy, in which suffering is unavoidable within samsara but samsara itself is not inescapable. Just as the self is broken down into multiple parts, Buddhism also breaks down the concept of suffering into three distinct categories.

There is basic suffering, suffering of change, and all-pervasive suffering. It is important to understand the distinctions between these forms of suffering, as they are caused by different circumstances and experienced in different ways.

The idea of basic suffering, or suffering-suffering, is an all encompassing concept that refers to all suffering inherent in the ‘lower realms’ of existence such as animal and human forms. This suffering is inherent in occurrences such as birth, sickness, pain, old age, and death — unavoidable facts of life.

Suffering of change, on the other hand, is best described as suffering caused by anything that is enjoyable to obtain, enjoyable to keep, and painful to let go of. This goes hand in hand with the concept of impermanence, which dictates that no matter how long something may last it will inevitably change or go away.

Therefore, no matter what it is that is bringing a being joy whether it be a person, place, or thing, it will inevitably be lost and suffering will ensue. This is especially pertinent in contemporary times, where we tend to define much of our lives by the material goods that we manage to acquire.

People gain immense pride and joy from their job titles, salaries, cars, houses, and relationships, growing only more attached to them as time passes. While this sort of lifestyle may bring joy in the short term, per the nature of suffering of change it will all eventually result in suffering no matter what.

Finally, the most intense form of suffering described in the Buddhist philosophy is the concept of all-pervasive suffering. This suffering is neither the result of natural processes nor material attachments, rather it is inherent in our very nature as beings that exist in samsara.

The logic here goes that even if we are not suffering in any given moment, we are still setting ourselves up for future suffering in various ways — suffering which we will inevitably experience as long as we remain trapped in samsara.

This is the most existential-dread inducing form of suffering for many, as it seems to almost write off the entirety of our measly Earthly realm as a pathetic cesspool of suffering. However, more so than simply making samsara seem bleaker than it already did, the point of all-pervasive suffering is a larger one, it is a reference to the achievement of enlightenment as the only light at the end of the tunnel.

This theme of achieving nirvana as the only escape from the cycle of samsara marked by suffering, impermanence, and non-self is essentially the holy grail of Buddhism.

Defying the precepts of samsara, to reach this state is to escape the thirty-first realm of samsara and fulfill one’s experience of all thirty-two parts of self, “And yet I do not say that one makes an end of suffering without reaching the end of the world.” (Gethin) This passage encapsulates what makes nirvana so unique, the fact that it is far beyond anything that could be achieved in this world, rather it is to transcend this world itself.

The preceding understanding of reality as a combination of suffering and impermanence as laid out by the Buddhist philosophy would be enough to inspire an existential crisis in many individuals, or at least close many of them off to considering the idea in earnest.

That is simply because in most parts of the world today people live lives with purposes that could not be more antithetical to the goals of Buddhism. As ultimately true as the Buddhist observations of non-self, suffering, and impermanence are, they are utterly unacceptable to most of our technologically advanced, globalized, modern twenty-first century society.

We live in a world where roughly eight men possess the same wealth as the 3.6 billion people who make up the poorest half of humanity, and where one in ten people survives on less than two dollars a day.

In my opinion, that is a world inhabited with people plagued by suffering because of their own inability to recognize how toxic their attachments have become. Not only have we strayed so far from being able to accept the impermanent nature of our reality, we have so fetishized materialism that we now view wealth as an end in and of itself rather than a means to an end — a tool to help others.

This has led to an extreme polarization of suffering into two distinct types endured by two distinct groups, suffering of change for those who relentlessly pursue materialism without ever attempting to grasp at greater purpose and suffering of suffering for the rest of humanity.

I knew a man who immigrated to the U.S. as a kid, started a successful business, bought a mansion and filled it with everything money could buy, yet ultimately remained so caught in a cycle of consumption that when his business plateaued and he had to sell his mansion he took his own life at fifty.

I have witnessed pure euphoria wash over a panhandler’s face as I handed them a twenty-dollar bill, and felt the abject terror of being robbed at gunpoint by a young man who appeared to be strung out on something serious.

The thing is, the person elated to receive a twenty, the wealthy man who took his own life, and my terrified self standing at the receiving end of a firearm all suffered for the same reason.

We suffered because we desperately sought permanence in an impermanent world, whether it was a desire to have enough money to eat, to continue chasing the dragon of consumerism, or continue living, we all wanted something of which there was no guarantee.

In this way, at the most fundamental level, all of life will always be suffering. Every moment we experience will inherently be shaped by past memories and is similarly subject to future expectations, therefore we will always suffer as long as we so much as have the slightest inkling of a desire for something to happen in the future or to hold onto anything from the past.

It is important to remember, however, that slapping the label ‘suffering’ on the entirety of the human condition does not mean life as a human is inherently bleak or unenjoyable.

Suffering is not a black or white, all or nothing experience — it would be an absurdly false dichotomy to claim that one either exists in a state of pure suffering or nirvana with no in between. There are quite a lot of shades of gray when it comes to suffering, which in my opinion are the secret to reconciling our existence in samsara.

The key to beginning to let go of some suffering and move into the lighter, more enjoyable shades is rather simple as well. It requires merely that one accept the impermanent nature of reality, something much easier said than done, but nonetheless a practice that can have a substantial effect on one’s degree of suffering.

Since I and most other people living today through our laptops, smartphones, and Facebook accounts are unlikely to actually accept the impermanent nature of reality, I prefer to instead ask us to confront the impermanent nature of reality.

By butting heads with the harsh reality that everything we care about from the tiny glowing screens in our palms to the buildings that keep us warm at night and the loved ones we hold dear are completely temporary, we force ourselves to experience a tiny bit of the impermanence that saturates the world around us.

Therefore, incrementally, we can begin to come to terms with what it means to live in an impermanent world.
title: Accepting Impermanence

Accepting Impermanence

How I learned to love Samsara

Jackie Thornhill
Apr 2

According to the Buddhist philosophy, the reality of existence is characterized by three distinct marks, impermanence, suffering, and non-self.

While these adjectives may initially seem to paint a bleak picture of the world, upon closer examination they are actually core tenets of an ideology centered around a unique cosmological and spiritual view of reality.

The idea of impermanence is crucial in Buddhism, as it posits that what we might cling to as permanent in our lives is all ultimately temporary. In the most basic scientific sense, this makes perfect sense.

For example — the half life of uranium might be an unfathomable period of time in the context of a human life, but nevertheless it remains an impermanent substance that will break down over time. Nothing exists forever, as the atoms that compose the world around us constantly take new forms.

Additionally, the idea of suffering is woven throughout the entirety of Buddhism. While some might think of suffering as a response to negative stimuli, whether it be physical or emotional pain, the Buddhist view goes a little deeper in examining the nature of suffering.

Rather than seeing suffering as an avoidable response to negative situations, Buddhism views suffering as an unavoidable consequence of attachment. Anything that gives us joy to acquire and joy to keep will inevitably cause us to suffer when we lose it.

Considering the impermanent nature of reality, anybody who attaches themselves to anything, be it an object, person, or place, is destined to suffer as a consequence. The third and final mark of reality is the concept of non-self, the idea that a person’s conceptualization of themselves is entirely impermanent and subject to change.

This is arguably the most difficult mark of reality to accept, as it requires us to let go of any concept of self that we may have acquired while existing in samsara and accept the transient, impermanent nature of reality — even when it comes to our own bodies.

This is difficult because we like to think of our lives as linear narratives that unfold at a daily pace, acted out by one evolving but ultimately unchanging person and bookended by our births and deaths. In reality, however, we are many different ‘selves’, there is no one unchanging being that remains with us throughout samsara.

In this way, the concept of non-self fits in well with the concepts of impermanence and suffering, as the nature of one’s own being is always impermanent and we only subject ourselves to suffering by growing attached to a concrete concept of self.

In Buddhist tradition many things that might otherwise be thought of as whole are broken down into smaller, more digestible parts. Existence is defined by three marks, reality broken up into six realms, and the body broken up into thirty-two unique parts. This distinction plays an especially important role when considering both the inevitability of suffering and the desire to escape it.

Professor of Buddhist studies Rupert Gethin writes, “There is some reason for thinking that the number thirty-two connotes completion and fulfillment in Buddhist thought: the body is described as consisting of thirty-two parts; the Great Man has a body with thirty-two marks. Yet samsara has only thirty-one realms.”

Gethin demonstrates the complexity of the concept of non-self and highlights the inescapability of suffering fwhile still allowing for the eventual escape from samsara. The self consists of thirty-two unique parts which aligns almost perfectly with the thirty-one realms of which samsara is made up, while providing for an alternative that represents nirvana.

This is exemplary of the Buddhist philosophy, in which suffering is unavoidable within samsara but samsara itself is not inescapable. Just as the self is broken down into multiple parts, Buddhism also breaks down the concept of suffering into three distinct categories.

There is basic suffering, suffering of change, and all-pervasive suffering. It is important to understand the distinctions between these forms of suffering, as they are caused by different circumstances and experienced in different ways.

The idea of basic suffering, or suffering-suffering, is an all encompassing concept that refers to all suffering inherent in the ‘lower realms’ of existence such as animal and human forms. This suffering is inherent in occurrences such as birth, sickness, pain, old age, and death — unavoidable facts of life.

Suffering of change, on the other hand, is best described as suffering caused by anything that is enjoyable to obtain, enjoyable to keep, and painful to let go of. This goes hand in hand with the concept of impermanence, which dictates that no matter how long something may last it will inevitably change or go away.

Therefore, no matter what it is that is bringing a being joy whether it be a person, place, or thing, it will inevitably be lost and suffering will ensue. This is especially pertinent in contemporary times, where we tend to define much of our lives by the material goods that we manage to acquire.

People gain immense pride and joy from their job titles, salaries, cars, houses, and relationships, growing only more attached to them as time passes. While this sort of lifestyle may bring joy in the short term, per the nature of suffering of change it will all eventually result in suffering no matter what.

Finally, the most intense form of suffering described in the Buddhist philosophy is the concept of all-pervasive suffering. This suffering is neither the result of natural processes nor material attachments, rather it is inherent in our very nature as beings that exist in samsara.

The logic here goes that even if we are not suffering in any given moment, we are still setting ourselves up for future suffering in various ways — suffering which we will inevitably experience as long as we remain trapped in samsara.

This is the most existential-dread inducing form of suffering for many, as it seems to almost write off the entirety of our measly Earthly realm as a pathetic cesspool of suffering. However, more so than simply making samsara seem bleaker than it already did, the point of all-pervasive suffering is a larger one, it is a reference to the achievement of enlightenment as the only light at the end of the tunnel.

This theme of achieving nirvana as the only escape from the cycle of samsara marked by suffering, impermanence, and non-self is essentially the holy grail of Buddhism.

Defying the precepts of samsara, to reach this state is to escape the thirty-first realm of samsara and fulfill one’s experience of all thirty-two parts of self, “And yet I do not say that one makes an end of suffering without reaching the end of the world.” (Gethin) This passage encapsulates what makes nirvana so unique, the fact that it is far beyond anything that could be achieved in this world, rather it is to transcend this world itself.

The preceding understanding of reality as a combination of suffering and impermanence as laid out by the Buddhist philosophy would be enough to inspire an existential crisis in many individuals, or at least close many of them off to considering the idea in earnest.

That is simply because in most parts of the world today people live lives with purposes that could not be more antithetical to the goals of Buddhism. As ultimately true as the Buddhist observations of non-self, suffering, and impermanence are, they are utterly unacceptable to most of our technologically advanced, globalized, modern twenty-first century society.

We live in a world where roughly eight men possess the same wealth as the 3.6 billion people who make up the poorest half of humanity, and where one in ten people survives on less than two dollars a day.

In my opinion, that is a world inhabited with people plagued by suffering because of their own inability to recognize how toxic their attachments have become. Not only have we strayed so far from being able to accept the impermanent nature of our reality, we have so fetishized materialism that we now view wealth as an end in and of itself rather than a means to an end — a tool to help others.

This has led to an extreme polarization of suffering into two distinct types endured by two distinct groups, suffering of change for those who relentlessly pursue materialism without ever attempting to grasp at greater purpose and suffering of suffering for the rest of humanity.

I knew a man who immigrated to the U.S. as a kid, started a successful business, bought a mansion and filled it with everything money could buy, yet ultimately remained so caught in a cycle of consumption that when his business plateaued and he had to sell his mansion he took his own life at fifty.

I have witnessed pure euphoria wash over a panhandler’s face as I handed them a twenty-dollar bill, and felt the abject terror of being robbed at gunpoint by a young man who appeared to be strung out on something serious.

The thing is, the person elated to receive a twenty, the wealthy man who took his own life, and my terrified self standing at the receiving end of a firearm all suffered for the same reason.

We suffered because we desperately sought permanence in an impermanent world, whether it was a desire to have enough money to eat, to continue chasing the dragon of consumerism, or continue living, we all wanted something of which there was no guarantee.

In this way, at the most fundamental level, all of life will always be suffering. Every moment we experience will inherently be shaped by past memories and is similarly subject to future expectations, therefore we will always suffer as long as we so much as have the slightest inkling of a desire for something to happen in the future or to hold onto anything from the past.

It is important to remember, however, that slapping the label ‘suffering’ on the entirety of the human condition does not mean life as a human is inherently bleak or unenjoyable.

Suffering is not a black or white, all or nothing experience — it would be an absurdly false dichotomy to claim that one either exists in a state of pure suffering or nirvana with no in between. There are quite a lot of shades of gray when it comes to suffering, which in my opinion are the secret to reconciling our existence in samsara.

The key to beginning to let go of some suffering and move into the lighter, more enjoyable shades is rather simple as well. It requires merely that one accept the impermanent nature of reality, something much easier said than done, but nonetheless a practice that can have a substantial effect on one’s degree of suffering.

Since I and most other people living today through our laptops, smartphones, and Facebook accounts are unlikely to actually accept the impermanent nature of reality, I prefer to instead ask us to confront the impermanent nature of reality.

By butting heads with the harsh reality that everything we care about from the tiny glowing screens in our palms to the buildings that keep us warm at night and the loved ones we hold dear are completely temporary, we force ourselves to experience a tiny bit of the impermanence that saturates the world around us.

Therefore, incrementally, we can begin to come to terms with what it means to live in an impermanent world.
